title: Bump to version 2.0.0
body: Because Wasmtime is a public dep, and that dep has bumped since the last release, we need to do a major version bump.

title: Re-export Wasmtime crate to allow easier use with Wizer API.
body: The Wizer API exposes several Wasmtime types, especially when using the functionality to provide a custom linker. It is thus useful to have a re-exported `wasmtime` to refer use when driving Wizer as a library, so versions do not need to be manually synchronized.

title: Allow a preloaded module to be used by the wizened module.
body:
This PR adds a `--preload` option to Wizer that allows the user to provide a second module (in addition to the module being snapshotted) whose exprts are available for import by the snapshotted module.

The preloaded module is not snapshotted, and is not linked or included in any way into the snapshot. Rather, it is assumed to contain intrinsics, stubs, helpers, or other stateless functions that are needed by the snapshotted module and that will also be available in its post-snapshot execution environment.

This option is useful for, e.g., implementing "intrinsics" for other Wasm-transform tools that are implemented as magic imports. These imports can be stubbed out during snapshotting, but preserved as calls to imports in the snapshot, to enable further processing.

title: Enable binary releases for AArch64 and s390x
body: Now that Wasmtime has been updated these should theoretically work according to the prior comments.

title: wizer.h: handle the case when wasi command main function returns non-zero code
body: When a wasi command's main function returns non-zero code, we should invoke `__wasi_proc_exit` for it. Closes #68.

title: Update Wasmtime to 8.0.0
Update to the latest wasm-encoder
body: Mostly just minor changes, nothing ground-shaking.

title: Update wasmparser to the latest version
body: Mostly just shuffling some bits around, shouldn't have any major impact on wizer.

title: Update wasmparser on the 3.0.0 update branch
body:
This is a PR to update the `jake/wasmtime` branch which updates Wasmtime to 3.0.0. I believe the main blocker on that PR was a failing multi memory test which was due to the `wasmparser` used by `wizer` being too old. This updates `wasmparser` across the "great module linking removal" which necessitated deleting a lot more code in wizer related to module linking. To the best of my knowledge that's in line with the original intention of https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wizer/pull/65 so I'm hoping it's ok. 

I'll note that I applied a mostly hack-and-slash approach to deleting module-linking code. I'm not intimiately familiar with everything deleted here.

title: fixup: release changes
body:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/@bytecodealliance/wizer is now live.

I had to make a couple of edits during the release process that were missed out of the version bump.

title: Bump version to 1.6.1-beta
body: Also this moves to `@bytecodealliance/wizer`. Version is suffixed `-beta` as we will only be updating on npm but not on crates.io.

title: Reduce the maximum number of data segments.
body:
Fixes #70.

We've found that in some cases, Wizer can generate too many data segments, such that we hit tool or engine limits elsewhere. Beyond a reasonable number, many tiny data segments can also result in less efficient processing overall, as well. This PR alters the constant in Wizer's internal memory-snapshot generation to force coalescing of segments beyond a limit of 10k, rather than the current 100k.

title: Implement SIMD128 support
body: This patch adds SIMD128 support to wizer.

title: update to wasmtime 4
body: This commit updates to the latest wasmtime - I've opened it as a separate PR as we may want to land this after landing and releasing the update to wasmtime 3

title: update to wasmtime 3.0.0
body:
wasmtime 0.38.0 removed it's module linking implementation to make room for the upcoming support for the component model. https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/3958

This PR removes all the module linking functionality from wizer and updates to wasmtime 0.38.0

This PR also changes from using `Trap::new` to using the `anyhow!` macro, `Trap::new` was removed in wasmtime 3.0.0 https://github.com/bytecodealliance/wasmtime/pull/5149



I've not worked much (if at all) in the wasmtime or wizer codebases, I may have done many things which are not correct here, hopefully it's along the right tracks 🤞

title: Update wizer.h to reference __main_void or __original_main as needed
body:
Use the clang version to detect the version of wasi-sdk we're linking with, so that we can determine if we should reference `__original_main` or `__main_void`.

cc @sunfishcode

title: Bump crate version to 1.6.0
Emit the data count section during rewriting
body: We weren't emitting a new DataCount section during wizening, which was causing a failure with wasm produced by wasi-sdk-16.

title: implement partial bulk memory support
body:
This is an expanded version of #37 which explicitly supports `memory.copy`,
`memory.fill`, and `memory.init` but still rejects modules which use any other
bulk memory operations.

Signed-off-by: Joel Dice <joel.dice@fermyon.com>

title: Move to using the a similar cross-compiling workflow as wasmtime which enables binary compatible builds and compiles for more platforms
body:
These prebuilt binaries will eventually be used within a wizer npm package (which itself will be used within the `@fastly/js-compute` npm package).

I've tested both the macos builds and they are working 🥳 

I don't have a windows machine to test on and I don't have an x86_64 linux machine to test on unfortunately

aarch64-linux and s390x-linux are commented out due to build errors these errors are solved in a newer version of wasmtime, when wizer updates to the newer wasmtime then we should uncomment these builds

If you want to test out any of the prebuilt binaries, they are available to download at https://github.com/JakeChampion/wizer/releases/tag/dev

title: Add npm packages for each platform+architecture combination that we supply prebuilt binaries for
body: These will eventually allow users to run `npm install @bytecode-alliance/wizer` and have wizer available for use. The reason for publishing to npm is for other npm packages to be able to depend on wizer directly such as https://npmjs.com/@fastly/js-compute

title: Add release workflow which builds for multiple operating systems and architectures
body:
These can be used by people who want to install wizer without having to compile it themselves.
One such use-case would be the fastly compute runtimes which install wizer in their CI environments.

title: chore: Update wasmtime to v0.35.3
